newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn ends mostly firm as tour data waited.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn ends mostly firm as tour data waited.

text.p: CBOT corn futures closed mostly higher in anticipation of a bullish report from a Midwest crop tour of key corn states, traders said.
"They were waiting for the Pro Farmer report. People bought the market in anticipation of a bullish number," said Steve Bruce of E.D. and F. Man International.
Crop scouts overnight pegged Iowa's crop crop yield potential this year at 126.0 bushels, below USDA's August forecast for 129.0 bushels per acre.
The Professional Farmers of America tour ends late Friday in Des Moines, Iowa.
Weather patterns were still alive as a market topic.

There was some talk that a private meteorologist was forecasting warm weather in September. That scenario would help boost the maturity pace and possibly enhance yield potential of the U.S. corn crop.
But most traders said today's market was mainly a position squaring affair amid thin volume.
"It's just chopping around and the volume is low," said Steve Bruce of E.D. and F. Man International.
Corn closed two cents per bushel lower to 1-1/2 higher, with September down two at $3.65-1/2.
ADM Investor Services bought three million bushels of March, Griffin Trading bought 1.5 million December and Rand Financial sold two million bushels of March, the traders said.
Corn futures volume was estimated at 47,000, down from 53,040 contracts Thursday, according to the CBOT.
Corn options trading was relatively quiet and the September expired quietly at 1201 CDT.
Corn options volume was estimated at 15,000, up from 13,819 contracts Thursday.
